Award.AwardTitle: What are the seismic expressions of deep thermal and thermochemical plumes?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hawaii and Iceland are classic examples of volcanic islands associated with dynamical upwellings (i.e., plumes) from the deep mantle. Plumes form naturally and abundantly in laboratory simulations of Earth convection. Yet, there is no consensus among Earth scientists whether rising plumes exist in the Earth. The burden is on seismologists to find expressions of plumes in seismic data. This proposal is aimed at identifying how physically plausible thermal and thermochemical plumes may perturb seismic waves and how these perturbations can be found in seismic data. The project will support one PhD student. The research expands an ongoing international collaboration that provides important international experience to the PhD student at Michigan and the two students in Europe who are directly involved in the project.
This proposal leverages significant investments made by the NSF in observational geophysics (including EarthScope and dedicated seismic arrays) by using the available data and providing a new, interdisciplinary investigation into the resolvability of mantle plumes by observational geophysics.

By combining multidisciplinary expertise, the work in this proposal will develop high-resolution simulations of plume formation and plume morphology and it will quantify the expected plume signatures in seismic data. The research involves computer simulations of thermal and thermochemical plume ascent, mineral physics calculations of the seismic wave speed variations within plumes, and 3D simulation of the distortion of the seismic wave field by plumes. Waveform and traveltime tomography and receiver function analysis of simulated waveforms will demonstrate how plumes are imaged tomographically and whether they produce observable deflections of phase boundaries in the transition zone.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The theory of plate tectonics predicts that volcanism on Earth occurs only at tectonic plate boundaries. Hawaii is one of many volcanic islands that break this rule. The prevailing hypothesis is that thermal instabilities near a depth of 2900 km (halfway to Earth’s center) rise as mantle plumes and produce the ‘hotspot volcanism in Hawaii. Many researchers from the Earth science community investigate the mechanisms of plume formation and ascent because plumes can potentially inform us of the composition of the lower mantle and how heat is transported from the deep interior to the surface by rock flow (i.e., convection). The four-month long eruptions on Kilauea’s Lower East Rift Zone in 2018 underscore the societal relevance of volcano research (see the description by the USGS Hawaiian Volcano Observatory at https://volcanoes.usgs.gov/observatories/hvo/).

Experimental fluid mechanics predicts that mantle plumes form naturally and abundantly within the thermal boundary layer above the core- mantle transition where Earth’s temperature increases by about 1000 ºC. However, there is no consensus among Earth scientists whether Hawaii is a hotspot above a mantle plume or, indeed, whether mantle plumes exist at all in Earth. The elevation of the seafloor and the chemical characteristics of erupted basalts are key geophysical and geochemical arguments in favor of the plume hypothesis but direct evidence for plume ascent in the mantle is scant.

During the past two decades, several groups have detected mantle plumes in seismic images of Earth's interior. These images were produced by computer-assisted tomography (CAT), a scanning technique similar to X-ray scanning in medical radiology but applied to earthquake-generated seismic waves. Our work was aimed at addressing the quality of seismic tomography and specifically how physically plausible plumes may appear in the images.

By combining our team's expertise in seismic tomography, fluid dynamics, mineral physics, and computer modeling, we developed high-resolution simulations of plume formation and plume morphology and quantified how the high temperature within plumes affect the wave-speed structure of Earth. Using supercomputers from XSEDE, funded by the NSF, we simulated seismic wave propagation to estimate the deceleration and distortion of seismic waves by plumes. We determined that the delay of seismic waves by plumes is smaller than 1 second on a total propagation time between earthquake and seismograph of 20 minutes. Our reconstructions of theoretical plumes indicate that plumes in Earth are resolvable across the mantle with seismic tomography when the uncertainty in the measured propagation time is smaller than 0.5 s. Such precise measurements will require the deployment of wide and dense arrays of ocean-bottom seismometers on the seafloor.

Spin-off projects show that plumes can amplify waves but this effect due to wave diffraction (lensing) is observed in narrow window and cannot be easily distinguished from intrinsic wave attenuation and scattering in the mantle and crust. Further, we mapped layering of the mantle beneath the USArray and found that strong wave reflections from a depth of 600 km beneath Gulf of Mexico region may signify the stagnation of an oceanic plateau that subducted into the North American mantle during plate tectonic convergence in the Jurassic period.

This NSF funded project led to five peer-reviewed journal articles and one chapter in a research monograph. It supported the PhD research of graduate student Ross Maguire, who developed skills in all aspects of the project including data acquisition, software development, application for compute resources at XSEDE, and the analysis of all simulations. He is currently an NSF Postdoctoral Fellow at the University of New Mexico.
